lexUnit.name: fashion.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: make into a particular form or article.

sentence.text: WHEN Fattorini & Sons , of Birmingham , were commissioned to fashion a trophy for a new competition to be run by the Essex Football Association in 1882 they really went to town .

Challenging themselves to fashion something beautiful from their desolate lot , they score with the crunchy hymn to friendship ` Palomine " , here included as both clenched-fist stomper and much more approachable strung-out slowie .
Born of Dilga , the Earth Mother , they fashioned the first genitals from the magic fungus for the hitherto sexless and infertile humans who had aimlessly wandered the earth .
It was fashioned from dark green plastic , wafer thin , yet of considerable weight .
Carefully , almost lovingly , he pulled the instrument across his knees and began to pluck at the strings with a plectrum fashioned from tortoise-shell .
Tab the tinker , who had come in to be shriven , had agreed to fashion a coffin of sorts out of thin planks of wood .
In five minutes she 'd fashioned a ring out of the wire .
` The witch cuts the hand from a murdered man then fashions a candle out of human grease which is lighted and put into the hand .
The man who fashions a visionary ideal of community demands that it be realized by God , by others , and by himself .
` Can we fashion some sort of stretcher ?
It is always possible to fashion a principle to fit the argument of the moment .
A grotto fashioned out of chicken wire and concrete is lit by a stained glass window featuring an Eastern scene.A stream trickles into 2 pools and on the bank sits a treasure chest .
It was fashioned of sandalwood , beautifully carved , and no larger than was needed to hold a psalter .

Chinese and Russian supply policies are key to whether Iran will successfully acquire the needed technology , expertise , and infrastructure to manufacture the fissile material for a weapon and the ability to fashion a usable device .
Obsidian is a hard , vitreous volcanic rock , which could be fashioned into tools for cutting and stabbing .
